catalyst.source: In this work, we demonstrated the successful construction of metal-free zerodimensional/two-dimensional carbon nanodot (CND)-hybridized protonated g-C 3 N 4 (pCN) (CND/pCN) heterojunction photocatalysts by means of electrostatic attraction.
catalyst.context: In this work, we demonstrated the successful construction of metal-free zerodimensional/two-dimensional carbon nanodot (CND)-hybridized protonated g-C 3 N 4 (pCN) (CND/pCN) heterojunction photocatalysts by means of electrostatic attraction.We experimentally found that CNDs with an average diameter of 4.4 nm were uniformly distributed on the surface of pCN using electron microscopy analysis.The CND/pCN-3 sample with a CND content of 3 wt.showed the highest catalytic activity in the CO 2 photoreduction process under visible and simulated solar light.This process results in the evolution of CH 4 and CO.The total amounts of CH 4 and CO generated by the CND/pCN-3 photocatalyst after 10 h of visible-light activity were found to be 29.23 and 58.82 molg catalyst -1 , respectively.These values were 3.6 and 2.28 times higher, respectively, than the amounts generated when using pCN alone.The corresponding apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) was calculated to be 0.076.Furthermore, the CND/pCN-3 sample demonstrated high stability and durability after four consecutive photoreaction cycles, with no significant decrease in the catalytic activity.The significant improvement in the photoactivity using CND/pCN-3 was attributed to the synergistic interaction between pCN and CNDs.This synergy allows the effective migration of photoexcited electrons from pCN to CNDs via wellcontacted heterojunction interfaces, which retards the charge recombination.This was confirmed by photoelectrochemical measurements, and steady-state and time-resolved photoluminescence analyses.The first-principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations were consistent with our experimental results, and showed that the work function of CNDs (5.56 eV) was larger than that of pCN (4.66 eV).This suggests that the efficient shuttling of electrons from the conduction band of pCN to CNDs hampers the recombination of electron-hole pairs.This significantly increased the probability of free charge carriers reducing CO 2 to CH 4 and CO.Overall, this study underlines the importance of understanding the charge carrier dynamics of the CND/pCN hybrid nanocomposites, in order to enhance solar energy conversion.

catalyst.context: The 0D/2D CND/pCN hybrid heterojunction photocatalysts were successfully synthesized using a surface charge-facilitated electrostatic interaction approach (Fig. 1).Initially, bulk g-C 3 N 4 was obtained by using urea as the precursor, as in our previously reported procedure (Fig. S3 in the ESM) 43,44.The bulk g-C 3 N 4 was subsequently delaminated into 2D g-C 3 N 4 nanosheets via an ultrasonication-assisted process.This was followed by the protonation of g-C 3 N 4 by HCl to alter its surface change from negative (-15.3 mV) to positive (14.0 mV), as confirmed by zeta potential analysis (Fig. S4 in the ESM).The negatively charged surface of the pure g-C 3 N 4 was ascribed to the -C-Nmotifs in the g-C 3 N 4 framework 18.The CNDs in solution, which was synthesized by the NaOH-assisted ultrasonic treatment of glucose, possessed a high negative charge (-40.4 mV) (Fig. S4 in the ESM).This was attributed to the abundance of oxygenated functional groups on the surfaces of CNDs.By considering the oppositely charged surfaces and - stacking interactions, we surmise that the CND/pCN catalysts were constructed through electrostatic selfassembly between the negatively charged CNDs and the positively charged pCN nanosheets.A series of CND/pCN samples were synthesized with different proportions of CNDs (0.5 wt., 1 wt., 3 wt.,and 5 wt.).The CND contents were confirmed by TGA analysis (Fig. S5 in the ESM). heterojunction photocatalysts by means of electrostatic attraction.We experimentally found that CNDs with an average diameter of 4.4 nm were uniformly distributed on the surface of pCN using electron microscopy analysis.The CND/pCN-3 sample with a CND content of 3 wt.showed the highest catalytic activity in the CO 2 photoreduction process under visible and simulated solar light.This process results in the evolution of CH 4 and CO.The total amounts of CH 4 and CO generated by the CND/pCN-3 photocatalyst after 10 h of visible-light activity were found to be 29.23 and 58.82 molg catalyst -1 , respectively.These values were 3.6 and 2.28 times higher, respectively, than the amounts generated when using pCN alone.The corresponding apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) was calculated to be 0.076.Furthermore, the CND/pCN-3 sample demonstrated high stability and durability after four consecutive photoreaction cycles, with no significant decrease in the catalytic activity.The significant improvement in the photoactivity using CND/pCN-3 was attributed to the synergistic interaction between pCN and CNDs.This synergy allows the effective migration of photoexcited electrons from pCN to CNDs via wellcontacted heterojunction interfaces, which retards the charge recombination.This was confirmed by photoelectrochemical measurements, and steady-state and time-resolved photoluminescence analyses.The first-principles density functional theory (DFT) calculations were consistent with our experimental results, and showed that the work function of CNDs (5.56 eV) was larger than that of pCN (4.66 eV).This suggests that the efficient shuttling of electrons from the conduction band of pCN to CNDs hampers the recombination of electron-hole pairs.This significantly increased the probability of free charge carriers reducing CO 2 to CH 4 and CO.Overall, this study underlines the importance of understanding the charge carrier dynamics of the CND/pCN hybrid nanocomposites, in order to enhance solar energy conversion.
